name: Enterprise Analytics Dashboard - Discovery & Definition
description: Discovery and definition phases for enterprise analytics dashboard, stopping before solution development to validate problem with stakeholders

inputs.context: B2B analytics platform used by data analysts and executives. Current dashboard has low adoption among analysts (who prefer SQL) and executives complain they can't find insights. Goal: understand core problem before designing solution
inputs.initialResearch: Interviews with 20 analysts and 10 executives, observation of tool usage, analysis of dashboard usage patterns, competitive analysis

userInsights.insight: Analysts bypass dashboard to write SQL because dashboard lacks flexibility for deep analysis
userInsights.evidence: 85% of analysts use SQL directly. Dashboard usage: 15 min/week vs. SQL: 20 hours/week
userInsights.userQuote: The dashboard is too rigid. I can see surface metrics but can't dig deeper when I find something interesting. So I just write SQL

userInsights.insight: Executives want answers, not tools - they hire analysts to interpret data
userInsights.evidence: Executives spend <5 min/month in dashboard. 90% of data requests go through analysts
userInsights.userQuote: I don't want to explore data, I want to know: Are we on track? What's the problem? What should we do? I hire analysts for that

userInsights.insight: Current dashboard tries to serve both audiences and satisfies neither
userInsights.evidence: Dashboard is 'too complex for executives, too simple for analysts'
userInsights.userQuote: It's in this awkward middle ground. Not powerful enough for real analysis, but too complicated for quick answers

problemAreas.description: Analysts need depth and flexibility; executives need quick answers and insights
problemAreas.userImpact: Low adoption from both groups, analysts create separate tools, executives rely on manual reports

problemAreas.description: Tool designed for exploration but executives want curated insights
problemAreas.userImpact: Executives can't find insights in time-constrained schedules, analyst bottleneck

stakeholders.perspective: Need powerful, flexible tools for deep analysis. Want SQL-level control
Need quick answers to business questions. Don't have time to explore
needsAndGoals: Immediate answers to 'how are we doing?'

stakeholders.perspective: Want to reduce analyst burden of manual reporting while maintaining quality

problemStatement.statement: Analytics dashboards struggle to serve both data analysts and executives because analysts need flexible exploration tools while executives need curated insights, resulting in low adoption from both groups, analyst bottlenecks, and decisions made without data
problemStatement.who: Enterprise data teams serving both analyst and executive audiences
problemStatement.what: Struggle to create analytics tools that satisfy both audience needs
problemStatement.why: Fundamental tension between depth (analysts) and simplicity (executives)
problemStatement.where: Data dashboards, analytics platforms, business intelligence tools
problemStatement.when: Organizations try to build 'one dashboard for everyone'
problemStatement.impact: 85% analyst dashboard abandonment, <5 min/month executive usage, analyst bottleneck, decisions without data

designPrinciples.rationale: Better to excel at specific use case than be mediocre at everything. Accept that different users need different tools
examples: Separate 'Insight View' for executives from 'Analysis View' for analysts
Each view optimized for its purpose, not compromised for both
Clear entry points based on user intent
designPrinciples.tradeoffs: More complexity in product architecture, but better user satisfaction

designPrinciples.rationale: Executives need opinionated guidance; analysts need flexible power tools
examples: Executive view: Curated insights with clear narratives
Analyst view: SQL-level flexibility with visual builder
Bridge: Analysts can publish insights to executive view
designPrinciples.tradeoffs: Two design systems to maintain, but each serves its audience well

designPrinciples.principle: Insights Are a Product, Not a Byproduct
designPrinciples.rationale: Insights don't emerge from exploration - they must be crafted, reviewed, and curated
examples: Analysts craft insights with narrative and context
Insight library as primary product for executives
designPrinciples.tradeoffs: Requires analyst time to craft insights, but scales their impact

successCriteria.measurement: % of analysts using platform for deep analysis
Number of insights published per week

technical: Must integrate with existing data warehouse
Query performance under 5 seconds for executive views
business: Budget constraints limit AI/ML investment initially
user: Executives have limited time for training

opportunitySpace.description: Opportunity to fundamentally rethink analytics tools by accepting that different users need different experiences. Instead of one compromised tool, create purpose-built views that excel at their specific use case
opportunitySpace.potentialValue: Increase data-driven decisions by 3x, reduce analyst reporting burden by 50%, improve executive engagement 10x
risks: Analysts may resist curating insights for executives
Risk of creating silos instead of collaboration

nextSteps.rationale: Stopping at definition phase to validate problem statement and design principles with stakeholders before investing in solution development. Problem framing is novel ('insights as a product') and requires buy-in
stakeholderValidation: Present problem statement and design principles to data team leadership
Workshop with analysts: Are they willing to craft insights?
Validate with executives: Would curated insights meet their needs?
Confirm constraints and success criteria with product team
nextSteps.decisionPoint: After stakeholder validation, decide whether to proceed with Develop phase or iterate on problem definition
